channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19: Govt urged to do serology tests on border and isolation workers
item.description: A special type of blood test could give vital clues as to how an isolation hotel maintenance worker got Covid-19 from a woman he had never met.

item.title: Deadline for businesses to display Covid Tracer QR code
item.description: Businesses have until noon today to display the government's Covid Tracer QR code before it becomes mandatory.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 18 August
item.description: It's been a busy day for Covid-19 news, and among it has been the mystery of how a worker contracted the virus, a security guard sharing returnee details via an app and a reporter finding the source of rumours about the South Auckland cluster.

item.title: Second NZ Post worker tests positive for Covid-19
item.description: New Zealand Post has confirmed a second worker at the Auckland Operations Centre in Highbrook has returned a positive Covid-19 test.

item.title: Residents caught between border forced to break Covid-19 restrictions to get food
item.description: Some residents in northern Waikato are having to break Covid-19 border restrictions in order to buy food.

item.title: Security guard suspended after breach at managed isolation
item.description: The minister in charge of managed isolation says she's confident the right processes were followed after a privacy breach at one of the facilities.

item.title: Finding the man behind the covid outbreak rumour
item.description: The man at the centre of rumours about a Covid-19 positive family that were condemned by the health minister has expressed regret after being tracked down.

item.title: Mandatory Covid-19 testing of all ports staff reined in
item.description: The government has backtracked on plans to urgently test every single person who had come into the Ports of Auckland for Covid-19.

item.title: Dementia facility tried to stop Ombudsman inspection
item.description: A secure dementia facility tried to stop the chief ombudsman inspecting their operation during the Covid-19 lockdown, despite him having the legal right too.

item.title: Family at centre of rumours struggling with online abuse
item.description: Fears about how the new coronavirus got past the border and back into the community is driving rumour, misinformation and online bullying, community leaders are warning.

item.title: Covid-19: Infected Rydges Hotel worker had no obvious contact with traveller
item.description: A worker at an isolation facility who tested positive for Covid-19 didn't have any obvious contact with the woman who carried the same strain of Covid-19, authorities say.

item.title: Man faces charges for allegedly trying to evade Auckland police checkpoint
item.description: More than 2200 vehicles have been turned around by police at the checkpoints on Auckland's boundary.

item.title: Live: Covid-19 updates for Tuesday 18 August
item.description: Read back on all that went down on 18 August via the RNZ live blog as Auckland discovered a case in the community not linked to the existing cluster.

item.title: Nelson council opts to refurbish old buildings rather than build new
item.description: Nelson councillors have opted to pursue plans for a $16.5 million refurbishment of existing premises, rather than build anew beside a central city river.

item.title: Demand high for Milford Track bookings as trampers snap up places in minutes
item.description: The Milford Track is set to sell out on its first day of bookings with more than 1000 made in about 10 minutes after sales opened. Less than an hour later, 97 percent of dates were full.

item.title: Auckland secondary schools cautious as 10 apply to run Year 12-13 classes
item.description: Some Auckland principals feel blindsided and undermined by the government's surprise decision to let some Year 12 and 13 students return to class.

item.title: Covid-19: 13 new cases of Covid-19 in community today
item.description: Director-General of Health Ashley Bloomfield says 12 of the new cases are linked to the community cases and one is under investigation but is believed to be linked.

item.title: Covid-19: Mount Roskill Primary School learning assistant tests positive
item.description: The Mount Roskill Primary School staffer is one of the 13 new confirmed cases of Covid-19 announced today.
